clean_story:
Light pulses. Data at near-instant speed.

"Fiber optic" means sending information as flashes of light through glass threads thinner than a human hair.


Imagine whispering into a straw—and your voice arriving across the ocean before you finish speaking. That’s fiber optics, but with light instead of sound.

A single fiber strand carries data by flickering a laser or LED 200,000 times per second. Each flicker is a binary digit—like Morse code, but for computers. No electricity. No overheating. Just pure, unobstructed light.

In 1988, the first transatlantic fiber cable (TAT-8) linked the U. S. , UK, and France. It handled 40,000 phone calls simultaneously—a leap from copper wires, which maxed out at 1,380. Today, a cable like MAREA (Microsoft/Facebook) streams 160 terabits per second—enough to download every movie ever made in under a minute.

Speed isn’t just about raw power. Fiber’s glass core reflects light inward, trapping it like a mirror maze. This "total internal reflection" lets signals travel 70% the speed of light in a vacuum—faster than radio waves or electrical pulses.

Three related subjects are quantum internet protocols, undersea cable ecosystems, and laser pulse precision.
